change: Resolved autonomy boundary contradiction in Section 11. Added bright-line rule: conformance to standards in new code is silent; restructuring existing code is ask-first. Clarified apply-silently list with concrete examples. Clarified ask-before list to distinguish restructuring from conforming. Falsified against 8 scenarios.

Added error budget guidance to Section 18. Inserted after SLO definitions: error budget formula, 4-tier spending strategy (>50% ship aggressively, 25-50% normal pace, <25% freeze risky deploys, exhausted feature freeze). Fills the #1 gap making SLOs actionable for velocity-vs-reliability decisions. Falsified against 5 scenarios including threshold variability and multi-service concerns.

Compressed Section 1 (Git) by ~20%. Eliminated 7 categories of redundancy: semver mapping prose to shorthand, Law 2 exhaustive separation mappings, Law 4 scan instructions duplicating Pre-Commit Protocol, Law 5 prose duplicating command lists, fixup workflow duplication between Branching and Advanced Workflows, dependency-order commits duplicating Law 3, file rename duplicating Law 2. All Five Laws preserved. Pre-Commit Protocol untouched. Zero behavioral changes.

Added delineating sentence to Section 21 clarifying relationship with Section 10: Section 10 owns deployment requirements/infrastructure, Section 21 owns pipeline gates/execution. Analysis found the overlap is requirement-vs-implementation pattern (not harmful redundancy), but lacked explicit delineation. Zero contradictions found. Downgraded from Priority 1 on frontier.

Compressed Section 12 (Debugging) by ~325 words. Four surgical edits: (1) Decision tree replaced leaf-node restatements with phase references, keeping only novel branching logic. (2) Anti-patterns section compressed 5 redundant entries to name+rule-reference format, kept 3 unique entries intact. (3) Phase 4 commit examples condensed from verbose bodies to structure+subject-lines with format cross-reference to Section 1. (4) Git bisect tutorial reduced from step-by-step ceremony to principle+automation-tip. All 6 phases, 5 fix quality rules, emergency hotfix protocol, and temporary debug logging protocol preserved. Zero behavioral standards lost.

Clarified 'max 3 parameters' rule in Section 3 with scope qualifier: applies to signatures you define, not callback signatures imposed by frameworks or runtime APIs. Analyzed 4 edge cases (constructors, config objects, callbacks, math functions). Only callbacks had genuine ambiguity; constructors and config objects work correctly under existing rule; math functions too rare and abuse-prone to codify exception. +17 words.

Added resource cleanup and graceful shutdown guidance to Section 3. Two additions: (1) RESOURCE CLEANUP rule requiring finally blocks for all acquired resources (DB transactions, file handles, streams, event listeners) — generalizes the Section 15 lock-specific finally mention into a universal principle. (2) GRACEFUL SHUTDOWN pattern (SIGTERM → stop accepting → drain in-flight → close pools → exit) — provides the process-level mechanism required by Sections 10/14/21 zero-downtime deployment rules. Resolves implicit contradiction: document required zero-downtime deploys without providing the enabling mechanism. Addresses #1 class of production failures in Node.js/Python: connection pool exhaustion and killed in-flight requests.

Added DEPENDENCY DELIVERY mechanism to Section 2. Services must receive adapters via constructor or factory parameters, never via direct import of adapter instances. Fills mechanism gap: Section 2 defined dependency direction (handlers→services→core→adapters), Section 5 required mock-at-boundaries testing, but neither specified how services actually receive their adapter dependencies. Without this, developers import adapters directly in services (tight coupling, untestable without module mocking hacks). The rule connects architecture (Section 2) to testability (Section 5) by providing the explicit wiring pattern both implicitly require.

Added OFFSET pagination performance warning to Section 7. Inserted after LIMIT/OFFSET guidance: warns that OFFSET is O(n) in skipped rows and directs to keyset/cursor pagination per Section 13 for tables exceeding 10K rows. Resolves inconsistency where the Performance section taught an anti-pattern without caveat while the API section (Section 13) correctly recommended cursor pagination for large datasets. Cross-reference aligns both sections.

Added REQUEST ID PROPAGATION mechanism to Section 8 (Logging). Section 8 required 'request ID for tracing' and 'propagate across service boundaries' but never specified how request IDs are generated, attached to context, or forwarded. Section 12 (Debugging) also depends on request IDs being available. Added 4-step mechanism: middleware generates UUID from X-Request-ID header or creates new one, attaches to request context for automatic logger inclusion, forwards on outbound HTTP calls, includes in async message envelopes. Same class of cross-section mechanism gap as iterations 27 (graceful shutdown) and 28 (dependency delivery).

change_summary: Add RESPONSE SERIALIZATION SAFETY to Section 6: mandate allowlist-based response shaping with explicit mapping functions instead of raw domain/DB object serialization

Add injection pattern scanning to Section 21 CI gates: merge gates now require scanning for string-interpolated SQL, unparameterized shell execution, and raw HTML assignment per Section 6. Pipeline stages include injection pattern scan alongside security scan. Closes the last enforcement gap: Section 6 absolute rules now have automated CI verification.

Add DEPRECATION LIFECYCLE to Section 13: deprecated endpoints return Deprecation (RFC 9745) and Sunset (RFC 8594) headers, mark deprecated in API spec with migration guidance, log at warn level per Section 8, monitor traffic before removal, return 410 Gone after sunset date, require zero traffic for 30 days before removal. Closes the API lifecycle gap: document now covers creation through versioning through deprecation through removal.

Add FEATURE FLAG LIFECYCLE to Section 10: every flag has a type (release/ops/experiment/permission), every flag has an owner, stale release/experiment flags are dead code to be deleted, never reuse a flag name. Fills the gap between directing teams to use feature flags and providing zero lifecycle management guidance. Prevents flag debt accumulation (Uber 6000+ stale flags) and flag name reuse ($465M Knight Capital incident).

Compress Section 3 (Code Standards) naming conventions and error class examples. Removed '(yes)'/'(no)' markers and parenthetical explanations from 8 naming rules. Removed InsufficientFundsError example (third repetition of extend-AppError pattern; NotFoundError + ValidationError sufficient). All naming rules, negative examples, and behavioral standards preserved. ~115 words saved.

Compress Section 13 (API Design Standards). Two edits: (1) Status code list reduced to non-obvious distinctions only — removed obvious codes (200, 204, 400, 404, 500) and duplicate 201, kept 401 vs 403, 409, 422, 429 which prevent actual mistakes. (2) Removed idempotency implementation sentence (how-to, not standard) and compressed 'prevents' list from three examples to precise term. All REST conventions, response envelope, pagination, versioning, deprecation lifecycle, rate limiting, and idempotency standard preserved. ~57 words saved.

Final state declaration. Section 14 assessed at compression floor (27 words / 6.4% — below cost-benefit threshold, not applied). GraphQL standards and monorepo guidance moved to graveyard. All frontier items resolved or graveyarded. Document declared at final state: ~11,431 words, 26 sections, 0 contradictions, 0 gaps, 0 enforcement holes. Net -237 words from start with 11 new concepts added.

Fix 3 self-contradictions: (1) hotfix() commit type in Section 12 changed to fix() per Section 1 type list, (2) SELECT u.* in Section 7 N+1 example changed to enumerate columns per own Never SELECT * rule, (3) Section 15 retry rule clarified: Never retry 4xx except 429. New lens: self-contradiction audit (does the document violate its own rules?). All 3 fixes are surgical single-sentence edits.

Fix cross-reference integrity issues: (1) Section 12 Phase 4 commit examples shortened to comply with Section 1's 50-char subject line rule — all four were 52-70 chars, now 42-49. (2) Decision Tree reference corrected from 'Phases 1-5' to 'Phases 1-6' since Section 12 defines 6 phases. New lens: cross-reference integrity audit (do examples in section X comply with rules in section Y? do internal references point to correct content?). Also identified low-severity 'No any ever' vs 'without justification' contradiction — deferred to frontier.

Resolve last internal contradiction: any/unknown inconsistency between Section 3 (No any ever) and Section 11 (without justification). Applied Section 3 existing escape hatch pattern from as assertions: any is prohibited unless unavoidable (FFI, third-party type deficiency) with a comment explaining why unknown is insufficient. Section 11 without justification framing now consistent. Internal contradictions: 0.

Add VERIFY BEFORE GENERATING rule to Section 9 step 2: before calling any project dependency or internal module API, read the actual definition or type signature. Never generate calls from memory alone. New lens: audience fitness (does the document's rules match the failure modes of its primary consumer — an AI coding agent?). Addresses the #1 class of AI agent failures: hallucinated API calls and assumptions about code without reading it.

Fix self-contradiction in Section 3: "No boolean parameters" bans its own solution (options object with boolean field). Added word "positional" to scope the rule correctly: "No positional boolean parameters." Same class of self-contradiction as iteration 38 findings, discovered through re-evaluation of low-severity observations.

Fix cross-reference gap in Section 21: coverage threshold CI gate now references Section 5's per-layer thresholds. Changed 'enforce coverage thresholds' to 'meets per-layer thresholds per Section 5'. Same cross-reference pattern as iterations 29 (OFFSET → S13) and 31 (architecture → S2). Closes gap where CI enforcers had no guidance on what thresholds to use.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied two new audit lenses: (1) numeric constraint consistency — extracted all thresholds and verified no conflicts when rules are applied simultaneously (handler 15-20 vs function 30, utility 50 vs dependency 50, coverage targets vs CI gates, performance budgets vs SLOs all consistent). (2) Actionability audit — verified action specifications are appropriately detailed or intentionally heuristic. Moved Cross-Language Contamination Guard to graveyard. Frontier now empty (0 active items). 17 distinct lenses applied total.

Forward reference & terminology audit. Fix 1: Section 11 "pre-commit verification protocol" changed to "Pre-Commit Protocol" to match canonical name from Section 1 (-1 word). Fix 2: Section 7 cursor pagination forward reference given inline definition "(client passes the last-seen sort key instead of a page number)" so reader can follow instruction without jumping to Section 13 (+12 words). New lens: forward reference audit (reader-experience dimension, orthogonal to all 17 previous content/audience lenses). 18 distinct lenses now applied.

Implicit temporal ordering audit. Section 12 Phase 4's three-commit bugfix structure (Commit 1 = failing test) directly contradicts Section 1 Law 1 (every commit must be bisect-safe with passing tests). Added squash note to Phase 4: 'Squash Commits 1 and 2 before merging to the target branch so the failing-test intermediate state never exists in shared history and Law 1 bisect-safety holds.' New lens: implicit temporal ordering (structural-interaction dimension, checks cross-rule state invariants). 10 findings evaluated, 1 applied, 9 rejected as derivable from existing patterns or low leverage. 19 distinct lenses now applied.

Add merge conflict markers to Pre-Commit Protocol Step 4 contamination scan. Existing scan checked for debug artifacts (console.log, TODO, etc.) but not merge conflict markers (<<<<<<< ======= >>>>>>>). These survive build in non-compiled files (YAML, JSON, Markdown, config) causing silent runtime failures. Particularly relevant for AI agents performing git rebase/merge operations. New lens: missing negative guidance (are there critical contamination patterns the scan does not detect?). 20 distinct lenses now applied.

Add FEATURE FLAG IMPLEMENTATION pattern to Section 10. New lens: prerequisite chain completeness (does every instruction have an actionable implementation path?). Feature flags were referenced as emergency escape hatch in 3 sections but had zero implementation guidance — lifecycle rules described metadata about a system the document never told you how to build. Added: flags are adapters per Section 2, code pattern isEnabled(flagName, context), ops flags must be toggleable without deployment. 21 distinct lenses now applied.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied failure mode asymmetry lens: enumerated all failure modes by severity (CATASTROPHIC/HIGH/MEDIUM/LOW), counted protective rules per mode, checked proportionality. Found 3 potential gaps (ongoing dependency monitoring, concurrent write identification, request ID enforcement) — all rejected as tool-specific, design judgment, or already covered by adjacent mechanisms. Protective density is well-calibrated: CATASTROPHIC modes have 2-6 layers, HIGH have 2-3, MEDIUM have 1 with complete patterns, LOW have 1 with examples. 22 distinct lenses now applied.

Fix constraint stacking deadlock in Section 20: refactoring that reveals a bug only testable post-refactor created a deadlock between S20 (stop and fix separately), S12/S5 (write failing test first), and Law 1 (bisect-safe). Added exception: complete behavior-preserving refactor commits first then immediately follow with bug fix commits against the refactored code. New lens: constraint stacking composability (do rules from different sections compose cleanly when applied simultaneously?). 5 scenarios tested: 1 deadlock fixed, 2 graveyarded as too niche, 2 confirmed clean. 23 distinct lenses now applied.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied error recovery path completeness lens: audited 9 multi-step procedures for unstated failure-branch recovery paths. Found 5 LOW-severity gaps (S9 step 2→3 implicit gate, S12 three-commit conditionality, S14 partial backfill recovery, S22 JWT overlap duration, S15 retry exhaustion) — all derivable from adjacent rules and below editing threshold. Document error handling architecture (S3: handlers catch, services throw) serves as universal implicit recovery mechanism. Cross-reference verification confirmed all 11 references remain accurate. 24 distinct lenses now applied across 9 meta-categories.

Add JSON key naming convention to Section 3 and fix mixed camelCase/snake_case in Section 8 log example. New lens: cross-format consistency (do structured output formats across sections use consistent naming and serialization conventions?). Audited 6 formats across 6 sections. Found 1 MEDIUM-severity gap: no JSON key convention declared, and Section 8 example mixed camelCase (userId) with snake_case (duration_ms) in the same object. 6 LOW findings rejected as correct-by-design or below threshold. Edit 1: added camelCase JSON key convention to S3 naming rules with IoT/hardware carve-out. Edit 2: fixed S8 duration_ms to durationMs. 25 distinct lenses now applied.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied trust boundary transition lens: traced data flow across 12 system trust boundaries (inbound HTTP, handler→service, service→DB, DB→service, response serialization, shell, HTML, config, message queue, device→server, outbound HTTP, WebSocket). 11 boundaries have explicit rules in specific sections. 1 (outbound HTTP/SSRF) is derivable from injection prevention pattern + adapter architecture. No MEDIUM or HIGH gaps found. 26 distinct lenses now applied across 11 meta-categories.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied rule verifiability lens: audited ~45 absolute rules across all 26 sections for mechanical verifiability vs heuristic character. Classified into 3 categories: mechanically verifiable (~25, have CI gates per iterations 31-32), review-verifiable (~15, covered by S25 review checklist), and heuristic (~5, correctly self-scope with judgment language like logical/specific/speculative). Zero false absolutes found — no rule claims mechanical enforceability while actually being heuristic. Two new low-severity observations added (test assertion logical scoping, cross-function lock analysis). 27 distinct lenses now applied across 12 meta-categories.

Scope boundary audit: fix 3 HIGH-severity scope gaps in absolute rules. (1) S14 every table → every entity table for created_at/updated_at, join tables need only created_at. (2) S2 max 300 lines → max 300 lines per hand-written source file, auto-generated and migration files exempt. (3) S2 one exported concept per file → type definition files in models/ may export cohesive group of related types. New lens: scope boundaries (does each absolute rule scope match its intended domain?). 14 MEDIUM findings rejected as below threshold. 28 distinct lenses now applied across 13 meta-categories.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Frontier exhaustion verification: independently attempted to find novel lenses after iteration 55 declared frontier exhausted. Evaluated 4 candidate lenses: (1) operational impedance mismatch — subsumes into prerequisite chain (iter 48) + actionability audit (iter 44), (2) resource pressure degradation — out of scope for aspirational standards document, (3) AI signal-to-noise — below threshold, human-team sections harmless per iter 49, (4) low-severity observation promotion — all 35+ items reviewed, none promoted. Confirmed document at content-optimal state. 29 distinct lens applications (28 unique + 1 exhaustion verification) across 13 meta-categories.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Fresh eyes verification: approached document from first principles rather than systematic lens application. Evaluated AI behavioral correctness failure mode (agents generating plausible but wrong business logic) — existing test-first discipline (S5, S9, S12) is the correct defense; no enforceable addition possible. Evaluated defense-in-depth completeness lens — subsumes into iteration 49 protective proportionality. Reviewed all 35+ low-severity observations — none promoted. Frontier exhaustion reconfirmed. 30 total lens applications (28 unique + 2 exhaustion verifications).

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied data invariant enforcement depth lens: should critical business invariants (balance >= 0, valid status transitions) be enforced at database level via CHECK constraints, not just application validation? Found legitimate MEDIUM-severity gap — database CHECK constraints not mentioned. Rejected: adapter architecture (S2) routes all DB access through adapters preventing most direct-write scenarios, boundary validation principle (S6) is derivable to database layer, S14 already covers NOT NULL constraints as the most common case. Specialization of iteration 53 trust boundary audit. 31 total lens applications (28 unique + 3 verification/rejection passes). Document remains at content-optimal state with 4 consecutive zero-edit iterations.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied end-to-end scenario simulation lens: walked through 4 realistic multi-section scenarios (new REST endpoint + migration, production race condition fix, API deprecation lifecycle, new team member onboarding) spanning 18/26 sections. All scenarios produce correct results when following document instructions exactly — no missing handoffs, contradictory guidance, or unclear transitions. Novel verification category: practitioner walkthrough (previous verifications were structural analysis). 5th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 32 total lens applications (28 unique + 4 verification/rejection passes). Document remains at content-optimal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied adversarial compliance testing lens: tested 10 scenarios where a practitioner tries to satisfy the letter of rules while violating their spirit (function length manipulation, test assertion combining, trivial regression tests, permissive validation, column enumeration, giant options objects, micro-commits, security scan evasion, numeric boolean substitution, flag name near-reuse). All 8 genuine attacks blocked by document's consistent mechanical-constraint + intent-clause pairing pattern. 2 scenarios correctly permitted as non-attacks. Novel verification category: gaming resistance (previous verifications tested cooperative compliance and structural analysis). 6th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 33 total lens applications (28 unique + 5 verification/rejection passes). Document remains at content-optimal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied partial adoption safety lens: tested 5 decomposition scenarios (debugging without testing, git without workflow, performance without database, security without error handling, resilience without logging). All sections are self-contained and safe in isolation — cross-references are informational pointers, not prerequisite dependencies. Section architecture mirrors code architecture: cohesive, loosely coupled, independently valuable. Novel verification category: decomposition safety (previous verifications tested structural analysis, cooperative compliance, and adversarial compliance). 7th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 34 total lens applications (28 unique + 6 verification/rejection passes). Document remains at content-optimal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied misapplication recovery lens: tested 8 honest-mistake scenarios where a practitioner misunderstands a specific rule. 3 CAUGHT by structural friction (dependency direction violations create test inability; commit granularity violations caught by Law 2 + Newspaper Test). 3 PARTIALLY CAUGHT by review + indirect mechanisms (large options objects, non-failing regression tests, never-mock strategy). 2 SILENT but low-severity (enumerating all columns instead of needed ones, hand-rolled redundant validation in core) — inherently require context-dependent human judgment, no actionable edit possible without the document becoming tool-specific or prescriptive about developer cognition. Novel verification category: feedback loop adequacy for honest mistakes (previous verifications tested cooperative compliance, adversarial compliance, and decomposition safety). 8th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 35 total lens applications (28 unique + 7 verification/rejection passes). Document remains at content-optimal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied temporal obsolescence resilience lens: cataloged 14 technology-specific references and 6 paradigm coupling points. Found consistent "universal principle + concrete example + or equivalent escape hatch" pattern throughout — technology references properly scoped as illustrations, not mandates. Paradigm assumptions (REST, relational, client-server) are reasonable defaults with ADR alternatives. 3 LOW-severity observations added (rotation cadences, performance budget numbers, client-server assumption). Novel verification category: technology coupling analysis (previous verifications tested structural analysis, cooperative compliance, adversarial compliance, decomposition safety, and misapplication recovery). 9th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 36 total lens applications (28 unique + 8 verification/rejection passes). Document remains at content-optimal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied cognitive load under stress lens: tested 5 high-pressure scenarios (production down, pre-commit, bug reported, new endpoint, merge conflict) measuring decision path efficiency, cross-reference burden, and linearity. Found 3 HIGH and 2 MEDIUM scenario findings — all specific to human-audience format concerns (wall-of-text scanning, section discovery, decision tree placement). Critical falsification: the document primary audience is an AI agent that reads the full document into context window, rendering format/placement concerns moot. Content-level findings (S12/S26 cross-reference, merge conflict guidance, endpoint checklist) are either already handled by partial adoption safety or inherently judgment-dependent. 3 LOW-severity observations added. Novel verification category: decision path efficiency under cognitive constraints (previous verifications tested structural analysis, cooperative compliance, adversarial compliance, decomposition safety, misapplication recovery, and temporal obsolescence). 10th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 37 total lens applications (28 unique + 9 verification/rejection passes). Document remains at content-optimal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Terminal state assessment: evaluated 3 candidate lenses (instruction stability under context compression, composability with external tooling, multi-agent coordination). All rejected — context compression is system-level not document-addressable, tooling composability covered by tool-agnostic design principle, multi-agent coordination is orchestration concern outside scope. 11th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 38 total lens applications (28 unique + 10 verification/rejection passes). Protocol has reached terminal state — no novel lens can be found that is simultaneously (a) not subsumed by prior lenses, (b) addressable by document edits, and (c) meeting improvement criteria.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Attempted test execution order independence lens: should Section 5 explicitly require tests to pass in any execution order? Rejected — the existing "no shared mutable state between tests" rule is the root principle that makes order irrelevant. Adding explicit order-independence guidance would be redundant, following the same derivability pattern as iterations 58 (database constraints) and 51 (retry exhaustion recovery). 12th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 39 total lens applications (28 unique + 11 verification/rejection passes). Protocol remains at terminal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied imperative completeness lens: audited all directives for sufficient operands (WHAT/WHERE/WHEN). 7 findings at MEDIUM severity: (1) --skip threshold undefined, (2) resource cleanup doesn't map to firmware platforms, (3) 'production queries' scope for migrations, (4) OTA rollback least-specified directive, (5) DLQ alert threshold missing, (6) pre-commit grep doesn't catch modern token formats, (7) 'update documentation' artifact unspecified. All rejected — judgment-dependent, platform-specific, workload-dependent, or addressed by defense-in-depth. Novel verification category: imperative operand sufficiency (previous verifications tested structural analysis, cooperative/adversarial compliance, decomposition safety, misapplication recovery, temporal obsolescence, cognitive load, derivability). 13th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 40 total lens applications (28 unique + 12 verification/rejection passes). Protocol remains at terminal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied contradictory incentive audit lens: do any rule pairs create competing optimization pressures where pursuing one incentivizes violating another? 7 pairs analyzed: (1) commit-often vs reviewability-first ordering — resolved by fixup/squash workflow, (2) max-30-lines vs minimal-diff — resolved by bright line principle + Law 2, (3) regression-test-mandatory vs deploy-fast-tracked — resolved by Emergency Hotfix Step 6 deferral, (4) no-any vs third-party types — resolved by iteration 40 escape hatch, (5) one-export-per-file vs type cohesion — resolved by iteration 55 exception, (6) test-behavior vs mock-at-boundaries — complementary rules not in tension, (7) no-refactor-without-tests vs untestable-needs-refactoring — resolved by iteration 50 exception. All tensions pre-resolved. Novel verification category: incentive gradient analysis (previous verifications tested structural analysis, cooperative/adversarial compliance, decomposition safety, misapplication recovery, temporal obsolescence, cognitive load, derivability, imperative operands). 14th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 41 total lens applications (28 unique + 13 verification/rejection passes). Protocol remains at terminal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied polysemy audit lens: do any terms carry different meanings in different sections, creating misinterpretation risk? Audited 20 cross-section terms (boundary, contract, adapter, handler, validation, scope, context, pipeline, lifecycle, layer, module, interface, pattern, trust, schema, envelope, protocol, service, consumer, factory). Results: 8 CONSISTENT (same meaning everywhere), 9 CONTEXTUAL (different meanings but context disambiguates), 3 AMBIGUOUS (protocol, schema, scope). All 3 AMBIGUOUS findings below editing threshold: 'protocol' dual-usage (S11 vs S23) is a human-format concern irrelevant for AI consumer; 'schema' ambiguity in S1 commit ordering doesn't produce incorrect behavior; 'scope' ORM usage in S14 already disambiguated by 'or view' qualifier. Novel verification category: semantic consistency across sections (previous verifications tested structural analysis, cooperative/adversarial compliance, decomposition safety, misapplication recovery, temporal obsolescence, cognitive load, derivability, imperative operands, incentive gradients). 15th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 42 total lens applications (29 unique + 13 verification/rejection passes). Protocol remains at terminal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied composition minimality lens: are any rules strict logical consequences of other rules, making them removable without coverage loss? Tested 6 candidates: (1) 'Never SELECT *' vs 'select only columns you need' — different purposes (CI gate vs guidance), (2) 'test behavior not implementation' vs mock/refactor rules — broader principle not entailed, (3) 'never store local times' vs 'store UTC' — complementary positive/negative instructions, (4) 'linear history preferred' vs rebase instruction — rationale vs procedure, (5) 'never read process.env' vs config rules — different attack vectors, (6) 'circular imports are bugs' vs dependency direction — different violation scopes. All 6 rejected. Lens subsumed by compression passes (iterations 23-37) which already evaluated rule-level redundancy at multiple granularities. Remaining apparent redundancies follow intentional 'principle + prohibition + positive instruction' teaching pattern. 16th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 43 total lens applications (30 unique + 13 verification/rejection passes). Protocol remains at terminal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied degraded-mode operation lens: should the document address what happens when enforcement infrastructure (CI, linter, type checker, test suite) is itself broken or unavailable? Rejected — the Pre-Commit Protocol already serves as the manual degraded-mode equivalent of CI gates (grep for secrets, grep for contamination, visual review). Emergency Hotfix Protocol establishes "fast-tracked not skipped" principle. Specific tooling-failure guidance would violate technology-agnostic principle (same rejection pattern as iterations 37, 44, 58, 67). 17th consecutive zero-edit iteration. 44 total lens applications (31 unique + 13 verification/rejection passes). Protocol remains at terminal state.

Fix sequencing error in Section 12 Temporary Debug Logging Protocol: steps 4 (remove all) and 5 (convert useful ones) were in wrong order. Following literally would delete debug logging before it could be converted to permanent observability. Swapped to: step 4 convert useful logging first, step 5 remove all remaining. New lens: operational sequencing ambiguity (instruction step ordering correctness). Audited 15 sequential instruction sets across 10 sections. Found 3 HIGH candidates (Before Submitting rebase ordering, Emergency Hotfix baseline, Migration Phase 1 sub-ordering) — all rejected as mitigated by CI pipeline, derivable, or infrastructure-specific. 1 MEDIUM finding applied. 13 additional MEDIUM findings rejected. 32nd unique lens. First edit in 18 iterations.

Applied directive modality consistency lens: does the STRENGTH of each directive match the SEVERITY of violating it? Audited all directives across 26 sections. Found 2 HIGH modality mismatches: (1) Section 3 'Prefer discriminated unions over optional fields' — same paragraph calls the alternative 'wrong' and creates impossible states, but uses soft 'Prefer' language contradicting its own assessment. Changed to 'Use discriminated unions instead of optional fields'. (2) Section 13 'all POST and PATCH endpoints should support an Idempotency-Key header' — prevents duplicate financial transactions and data corruption but uses 'should' while every surrounding directive uses declarative imperative. Changed to 'support' (removed 'should'). 3 MEDIUM findings rejected as correctly calibrated: linear history 'preferred' (workflow choice), blue-green 'preferred' (infrastructure-dependent), raw literals 'never' (context clarifies intent). 33rd unique lens. 2 edits, -1 word delta.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied negative space coverage lens: do any 'wrong' examples describe patterns that are sometimes correct? Audited all 19 'wrong is' anti-pattern labels. Found 4 genuinely always wrong (SQL injection, shell injection, logging credentials, vague reviews), 1 nearly always wrong (dead code), 14 context-dependent. All 14 context-dependent labels already scoped by qualifying phrases (because/when/that/which clauses) that prevent literal misapplication. Zero HIGH findings — no false-negative anti-patterns. Novel verification lens: anti-pattern accuracy (tests whether negative examples are correctly scoped, distinct from adversarial compliance which tests reader gaming and scope boundaries which tests rule over-broadness). 34th unique lens. 47 total lens applications (34 unique + 13 verification/rejection passes). Document remains at content-optimal state.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied conditional reachability lens: when the document says 'if X, do Y', is Y always reachable from X's state? Audited all conditional instructions across 26 sections. Found 5 HIGH candidates: (1) S2 'must refactor' vs S20 'never refactor without tests' — resolved by S20 Step 1 'write tests first' gate. (2) S4 Object.freeze vs S10 runtime flag toggle — resolved by adapter pattern separating flags from frozen config. (3) S12 no-repro vs Emergency Hotfix — already in low-severity observations. (4-5) Emergency feature flag/rollback may not exist — infrastructure prerequisites, rollback provides alternative. 14 MEDIUM findings all below threshold. 35th unique lens. 48 total lens applications.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied example sufficiency lens: do rules lacking positive/negative examples risk misapplication? Audited all rules across 26 sections. Found 12 HIGH-severity findings (S3 resource cleanup, S3 graceful shutdown, S6 response serialization, S8 request ID propagation, S10 feature flags, S13 deprecation headers, S15 circuit breaker, S16 cache stampede, S17 optimistic locking, S21 CI gates, S23 offline resilience, S24 backpressure). All 12 rejected after falsification: (1) primary audience is AI agent that generates implementations from prose descriptions, (2) code examples would require language-specific implementations violating technology-agnostic principle, (3) would add 500-2000+ words to document at compression floor, (4) document is standards not tutorial — implementation HOW-TO gaps are by design. Novel verification lens: example coverage as disambiguation mechanism (distinct from actionability which checks detail sufficiency, negative space which checks anti-pattern accuracy, and self-contradiction which checks example-rule compliance). 36th unique lens. 49 total lens applications (36 unique + 13 verification/rejection passes). Third consecutive zero-edit iteration.

No edits to CLAAAAAAUDE.md. Applied rule enforcement stratification lens: should any rule be promoted from a lower enforcement tier (heuristic → review → CI gate → absolute prohibition)? Evaluated 7 promotion candidates: max 30 lines/function, max 300 lines/file, circular imports, N+1 detection, DB lock + HTTP call, one logical assertion, handler 15-20 lines. All 7 rejected — rules that CAN be mechanically verified are already connected to CI gates (iterations 31-32); remaining rules require human judgment, would produce false positives under hard enforcement, or would require tool-specific implementation violating technology-agnostic principle. Inverse of iteration 54 (rule verifiability): both directions confirm enforcement tiers are correctly calibrated. 37th unique lens. 50 total lens applications (37 unique + 13 verification/rejection passes). Fourth consecutive zero-edit iteration.
